intro: Carex sylvatica subsp. laxula, commonly known as the slender sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Cyperaceae family. It is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear wind-pollinated flowers. Native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere, it thrives in moist, well-drained soils, often found in forest understories or wetlands. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and is known for its ability to tolerate partial shade. Its ecological importance includes providing habitat and food for various invertebrates and small vertebrates.
